bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Ida E. Kissinger, June 9, 1941

div1.p: Hench expresses concerned about Kissinger's health.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Ida E. Kissinger, June 9, 1941
div1.p:
I have just returned from my Eastern trip, having gone to my
college's twenty-fifth reunion. While in Easton, my family sent a wire
telling me of Mr. Kissinger's serious illness. This has distressed me
greatly.

He told me that he had had some sort of an illness which made
me wonder whether he hadn't had a little stroke, but I didn't tell him
that. Nevertheless, he seemed so cheerful and happy, and made a short
but very nice little response when called upon to rise and receive the
acknowledgement of the audience. It was a small but a most appreciative
and distinguished audience. The President and President-elect of the
American Medical Association were there and deans of certain medical
schools, other well-known physicians and a number of directors of art
institutes. Mr. Kissinger captured the admiration of the audience and
many of them came forward to meet him and get his autograph as a souvenir
of a very pleasant occasion.

I most sincerely hope that you can write me that he is improving,
even though slowly. I know you must be greatly troubled but undoubtedly
his friendly physicians in Huntington are doing everything they possibly
can for him. If I thought there was anything in the world that I could do
I should be only too glad to do it but those things which can be done for
a person who has had a stroke are very limited indeed and undoubtedly they
are being done. Despite your anxiety I shall be so grateful if you would
keep me informed as to his progress.

Our hearts are with you and our prayers and thoughts are in his
behalf.
div1.closer: Very sincerely yours, P. S. Hench, M. D. psh:ds
